newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish Icopal upholds Phoenix bid.
newsitem.headline: Danish Icopal upholds Phoenix bid.

text.p: Denmark's Icopal said on Thursday it upheld its last bid for local roadbuilder Phoenix.
Last Friday, Norway's Rieber & Son raised its bid for Phoenix to 875.8 million crowns, matching a rival offer by Icopal.
After Thursday's Icopal announcement, Phoenix board chairman Henry Petersen told Reuters that it would recommend its shareholders to take the Rieber offer.
"The Phoenix board will present a recommendation within the next few days to shareholders to accept the Rieber offer. We have prepared our position, it only has to be confirmed now," Petersen said.
Both the Icopal and Rieber bids offer shareholders 790 crowns per share for A-shares in Phoenix Contractors and 710 crowns per share for C-shares.
Both bids expire on April 1 at 1500 GMT.
In a statement Icopal said it was upholding its original offer of March 1, which is identical to Rieber's latest bid.
"Consideration for our shareholders obliges us to limit our offer despite the major strategic importance of the takeover bid," Icopal said in a statement.
Icopal said its aim in making the bid for Phoenix was to enable structural rationalisation to take place within Denmark's roadbuilding industry to the benefit of competitiveness and employment.
In a comment Reiber managing direrctor Olav Daviknes told Reuters: "I am optimistic. Only a new offer can now block Rieber's chances of taking over Phoenix."
Thursday's statement from Icopal was the latest move in an increasingly bitter takeover struggle for Phoenix, launched by Rieber on January 15.

Heavyweight Danish construction and chemicals group Superfos, favoured by the pension funds which are Phoenix's largest shareholders, later made a higher bid but said it would not increase it again after Rieber leapfrogged ahead.
At one stage a fourth suitor for Phoenix, provincial Danish building contractor Marius Pedersen made an offer, but it expired two weeks ago.
The Phoenix board has earlier indicated its preference for Rieber on the grounds that the Norwegian firm seems more willing to respect the Jutland-based firm's autonomy and preserve jobs.
Rieber has a 25.7 percent equity stake in Phoenix with 23.1 percent of voting stock.
